results.title: The Carp = Saran
results.creator_credit: Vladimir Jutrisa, Alexsandar Marks and Zagreb Film
results.brief_description: Animator Aleksandar Marks is a master of several graphical styles. Philosophically, he feels at home in the world of Kafka, Camus, the Bauhaus, Kathe Kollwitz and German expressionism. His favourite topic is the increasing loneliness of human beings in the industrial society. This particular animated film tells the story of a small boy and an older man fishing together by a river. Later the boy catches a huge carp in a sweet shop where the fish proceeds to produce lots of sweets for the boy. Finally the boy floats away pulled along by a balloon. Animated by Alexsandar Marks and Vladimir Jutrisa.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vladimir Jutrisa, Alexsandar Marks and Zagreb Film

results.title: Raw fish and pickle
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey, Australia Japan Foundation and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Depicts life in a traditional rural province - Iwate Prefecture - and looks at attempts to improve Japan’s self-sufficiency in food. Also shows traditional fishing songs, traditional dancing and the Morioka Snow Festival. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Capitol
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The Capitol Theatre plays a vital part in the social life of Warrnambool. Built in 1929 and opened in 1930, in 2008 the cinema has been converted into three separate cinemas, run by General Manager, Greg Gent. Taking us on a tour of the historic cinema, Gent discusses the challenges of running a cinema in the DVD age.
Stan and Norma Stevens have been associated with the cinema for over 50 years where Stan first worked as an usher and the cinema was the setting for their first date. Noel Hallam worked at the theatre for 34 years and Ivan Berndt has been the projectionist for 37 years. Each has their own stories to tell on how the theatre has been an integral part of their lives and how it continues to be.

results.title: The Rice ladle
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Japanese women these days face difficulties, especially in the professions as society emphasises the traditional role as the home-maker. Looks at a widow working as a cook’s assistant and a girl studying to be a pop star.

results.title: A Working couple
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human Face of Japan”.
Most Japanese live in the big cities, many of them are salaried company workers, living in housing estates and traveling long distances to work. For many people, life is a struggle. This focuses of Mr Yokohama, a professional office employee and his wife who runs a chemist. Their lives provide an insight as to what its like to live in Tokyo, with a population of twelve million.

results.title: The Lorne Theatre
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Astrid Scott, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Established over 90 years ago, the Lorne Theatre came about when a travelling picture show man ran out of funds and some local business men purchased his equipment and started running movies in the local hall. It then moved to its present site in 1937, where for such a small permanent population, the theatre has not changed much in all those years. Tony Hill, Manager of the Lorne Theatre, talks about the difficulties in offering a diverse range of cinema in the climate of DVDs and downloadable movies, and operating in a town prone to blackouts. He is proud the theatre is attended by a local group of cinephiles who sit in the same seat every session, and thinks himself very lucky to have his job.
